Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding How Increasing Urbanization Affects Cultural and Biological Knowledge Preservation in Sichuan Province, China
Award.AbstractNarration:
China?s vast orchid diversity, particularly Southwest China?s Sichuan Province, is well documented. Many species are used in traditional Chinese medicine, with a long history of cultivation and cultural appreciation. Pressures resulting from their pharmaceutical potential, rarity, and beauty, and from habitat loss, risk extinction of many species. Due to the link between biodiversity and cultural diversity, documenting traditional orchid knowledge is necessary to conserve the orchid culture and diversity. Rapid urbanization and the acute economic pressures for rural communities to develop have increased endangerment of Southwest China?s biological and cultural diversity. In collaboration with Dr. Ya Tang, an accomplished environmental scientist and botanist at Sichuan University, this project will test the effect of urbanization on three types of orchid knowledge in Sichuan Province. The unique cultural and biological diversity of the province position this study to yield valuable insights for conservation efforts.

Though the orchid flora of Sichuan Province is the third most diverse in Mainland China, a dispro¬portionately small amount of research studies have focused there. Rapidly declining orchid populations are widely recognized, but little attention has been paid to formally documenting this phenomenon or investigating the impact of their loss. Urbanization and economic development pressures compound the endangerment of Sichuan?s biocultural diversity. This study asks what role urbanization has on the preservation/dissemination of orchid cultural knowledge in Sichuan, hypothesizing that the effect depends on the type of knowledge considered. To test this, an interdisciplinary knowledge survey, employing semi-structured interviews, will be conducted to assess impacts of urbanization on three types of orchid knowledge in Sichuan. Stakeholders in orchid biocultural diversity conservation such as government agencies, botanical gardens, and universities will benefit from the greater insight this project will provide for their initiatives. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As an EAPSI China 2015 fellow, I was able to conduct an interdisciplinary knowledge survey in Southwest China's Sichuan Province to assess the impact of urbanization on three types of orchid knowledge. This project tested the hypothesis that the effect of urbanization on cultural knowledge depends on the type of knowledge being considered, and it has profound implications for the conservation of biocultural diversity in China, the United States, and beyond. Collaborating with Dr. Ya Tang, an accomplished environmental scientist and botanist at Sichuan University, I chose three locales for this project in central and southern Sichuan due to their distinct levels of urbanization. All three have active orchid stakeholders with cultural and economic incentivization. Chengdu, the capital city (~14 million people), is the most urban and wealthy locale in the province. The other two locations are in the Liangshan Yi Autonomous Prefecture in southern Sichuan. These include a small majority-Han county of about 450,000 people called Huili, and two small (~150 households each), rural, Han-majority villages near Puge. The three levels of urbanization, therefore, are high (Chengdu), moderate (Huili), and low (villages).

During the 8-week EAPSI program term, as well as an additional month of self-funded field research, I was able to complete 90 interviews of orchid stakeholders, 30 each from Chengdu and Huili, as well as 15 from each village. Analysis of these interview data is ongoing, and I am currently preparing a paper for publication based on the results. The EAPSI 2015 program provided a nurturing environment for me to better understand the Chinese scientific processes, protocols, and infrastructure that will continue to help me throughout my career. I was also able to train several graduate students in Dr. Tang's lab on the research methods I employed (which are not commonly practiced in China), and I was asked to give two presentations on my methods at Sichuan University while I was in China.

China's vast orchid diversity, particularly in Sichuan, is well documented. Many species are used in traditional Chinese medicine and have a long history of cultivation and cultural appreciation. Pressures resulting from their pharmaceutical potential, rarity, and beauty, as well as from habitat loss, risk the extinction of many species. Due to the link between biodiversity and cultural diversity, a focused effort to document traditional orchid knowledge is necessary to conserve the orchid culture and diversity. Rapid urbanization and the acute economic pressures for rural communities to acculturate, modernize, and develop economically have increased the endangerment of Southwest China’s biological and cultural diversity. Few studies have investigated these phenomena in Sichuan, and the unique cultural and biological diversity of the province position this study to yield valuable insights for conservation efforts. Specifically, stakeholders in orchid biocultural diversity conservation such as government agencies, botanical gardens, and universities benefit from the greater insight this project provides for their initiatives.
